questions.question: What is “exposure” in photography?
options: The amount of light that reaches the camera sensor
questions.reviewHint: Exposure = brightness recorded by the sensor.

questions.question: The exposure triangle is made of…
questions.reviewHint: Only these three directly change brightness.

questions.question: Which setting controls how long light hits the sensor?
Which change makes a photo brighter by one stop?
questions.reviewHint: One stop brighter = double the light.

questions.question: Your picture looks too dark. Which single change will brighten it?
questions.reviewHint: Slower shutter lets in more light.

questions.question: Your indoor photo is blurry from hand shake. What’s the simplest fix?
In bright sun at ISO 100, which is a good starting point?
You want a blurry background on a portrait. What helps most?
questions.reviewHint: Wider aperture (smaller f-number) = shallower depth of field.

questions.question: Which histogram suggests underexposure?
options: Most of the graph pushed to the left
Most of the graph pushed to the right
A spike only in the middle

questions.question: Which pair is an equivalent exposure to 1/125s at f/5.6 (ISO 100)?
questions.reviewHint: One stop faster shutter + one stop wider aperture = same brightness.
